attributes.title: Stereotype-based employment discrimination of people with mental vs. physical disorders - Study 3

q1.value: Stereotype-based employment discrimination of people with mental vs. physical disorders - Study 3

q2.value: Deborah Borowski, Ramona Allstadt Torras, Angela Rachael Dorrough, Andreas Glöckner

q3.value:
The results of two previous studies show that people with mental disorders, as compared to people with physical disorders, are discriminated against in a hypothetical reintegration hiring scenario (Study 1 and replicated in Study 2) and that this hiring-bias might not be eliminated by a social norm or by monetary incentives not to discriminate (Study 2). Nevertheless, a monetary incentive not to discriminate tends to result in a greater reduction of the hiring bias than both, a social norm and a combination of the monetary incentive and the social norm. Given that social norms (Bresnahan & Zhuang, 2016; Goldstein, Cialdini, & Griskevicius, 2008) as well as monetary incentives (Mantzari et al., 2015; Shaw & Gupta, 2015) have been shown capable of influencing people’s behavior, these results seem to be counterintuitive. Therefore, one of the aims of the present study is to replicate findings of the above mentioned studies with improved material. More specifically, materials of the previous studies will be adapted in the following ways:

-	The norm used in Study 2 (“It is expected from the committee that all applicants are considered in the application procedure, irrespective of the reason for their previous absence from work.”) rather resembles a disjunctive norm, because it suggests “what others think should be done” (Chung & Rimal, 2016, p. 6). As previous studies indicated that descriptive norms might be more powerful to change people’s behavior (Melnyk, van Herpen, Jak, & van Trijp, 2019), the present study will use such instead. That is, the norm will be rephrased in such a way that it rather emphasizes “what others actually do” (Chung & Rimal, 2016, p. 6; “All members of the committee, to which you belong, ensure that all applicants are considered in the application procedure, irrespective of the reason for their previous absence from work.”).
-	To ensure that sufficient attention is paid to both, general instructions as well as the manipulation, the latter will be presented after the general instructions. Thus, due to this separation, the manipulation will be more salient.
-	Control questions yielding at the deepened processing and understanding of the general instructions and those provided in the manipulation will be administered. More specifically, in order to make sure that participants have fully understood the general instructions, a test trial will be implemented. To exclude the possibility of influences on subsequent measures, the test trial was based on Pattern 1 adopted from Dorrough, Glöckner, Betsch, and Wille (2017), which has not been utilized for subsequent measurements. Moreover, information with regard to gender and disorder of the applicants will be removed from the test trial. In addition, manipulation specific control questions will be utilized and presented on the same page as the test trial: If the condition entails the presentation of the social norm (i.e., Condition 2 and 4), a control question with regard to this norm will be integrated. If the condition contains a monetary incentive (i.e., Condition 3 and 4), a control question with regard to the incentive will be included. Thus, besides the test trial, participants will be asked to answer no additional question in Condition 1, one additional question in Condition 2 (i.e., with regard to the norm), one additional question in Condition 3 (i.e., with regard to the incentive), and two additional questions in Condition 4 (i.e., with regard to both, norm and incentive). Moreover, for each of these questions, only one of the possible answers will be correct. Participants will subsequently receive feedback and will be presented with the repetition of instructions, if necessary. To prevent selective dropout due to varying numbers of control questions and the possibility of differences in difficulty, participants will be allowed to answer them multiple times and can only proceed after answering all of the control questions correctly.
-	As a manipulation check, after assessment of the main dependent variables, participants will be asked to provide an estimate of the percentage of decisions that are solely based on job-related criteria since it is reasoned that participants who were presented with the descriptive norm (i.e., Conditions 2 and 4) should assume this percentage to be higher than participants who did not receive such information.
-	To reduce the possibility of fatigue effects, the variable “mental and physical demands due to a certain occupation”, which previously had been assessed for other purposes, will be excluded.


In addition, based on the Stereotype Content Model (SCM, Fiske, 2012), which assumes that social judgments are formed by stereotypical perceptions along the two dimensions of warmth and competence, Study 1 and Study 2 indicated that the hiring bias is also mediated by perceived competence associated with the disorder. Given that the SCM states that the most negative judgments arise if the target is perceived to be low on both dimensions (i.e., competence and warmth) and in light of evidence suggesting that disorders do not only differ with regard to their perceived competence, but also with regard to their perceived warmth (Sadler, Meagor, & Kaye, 2012; Fiske, 2012), the second aim of the present study is to examine whether mental as compared to physical disorders do differ with respect to their perceived warmth and whether this influences the hiring bias, too.

q4.value:
As the current study is intended to gather data for several purposes, all hypotheses are listed below. The hypotheses that will be tested within a master’s thesis are written in bold letters.

In addition, contrary to the previous studies, the replication hypotheses will be tested across all four conditions rather than only for Condition 1, because the relationships are expected to be found in all four conditions. This, in turn, might also result in greater power to detect the below described relationships.

Replication hypotheses concerning all four conditions:
-	H1: Across all conditions, the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is predicted in a rational manner by job relevant cues (positive relation).
-	H2: Across all conditions, the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is higher for applicants with physical as compared to mental disorders (main effect of disorder (i.e., hiring bias)).
-	If H1 and H2 are confirmed, the cue validity of the cue mental vs. physical disorder and how much better an applicant with a mental disorder has to be according to job relevant cues (delta Bayes posterior probability) to be preferred over a person with a physical disorder will be calculated.

-	H3: Across all conditions, the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is influenced negatively by the expected long-term impairment (difference between the more and the less suitable applicant). It is hypothesized that the expected effect of the cue mental vs. physical disorder is (fully or partially) mediated by differences in expected long term impairment.
-	H4: Across all conditions, people with mental as compared to physical disorders are perceived as being less competent (main effect of disorder).
-	H5: Across all conditions, the expected probability to be successful in the occupation is perceived to be lower for people with mental as compared to physical disorders (main effect of disorder).
-	H6: Across all conditions, the expected effect of the cue mental vs. physical disorder on the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is (fully or partially) mediated by perceived competence.

New hypotheses:
-	H7.0: It is hypothesized that in Conditions 2 (norm only), 3 (incentive only), and 4 (norm + incentive), the probability to choose the more suitable applicant will be higher in comparison to Condition 1.
      o	H7.1: The probability to choose the more suitable applicant increases with the presence of a social norm (main effect of norm).
      o	H7.2: The probability to choose the more suitable applicant with the presence of monetary incentives (main effect of incentive).
-	H8: Across all conditions, people with mental as compared to physical disorders are perceived as being less warm (main effect of disorder).
-	H9: Across all conditions, the expected effect of the cue mental vs. physical disorder on the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is (fully or partially) mediated by perceived warmth.

Explorative analyses:
It will be exploratively investigated whether the expected effect of condition on the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is moderated by perceived warmth of the disorder (i.e., interaction between condition and perceived warmth).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: The study design will be a mixed factorial design (for details, see also variables section).

q9.value:
Following variables will be randomized:
•	instruction (i.e., conditions)
•	occupation
•	presentation order of the 10 mental disorders
•	physical disorders will be randomly opposed to the 10 mental disorders (see also variables section)
•	gender of the applicants (see also variables section)
•	order of the patterns and the corresponding localization of the mental disorder (i.e., instead of reversing the patterns, the mental disorders will be located on either side)

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participant recruitment and payment:
•	Participants will be recruited from the Decision Lab Cologne pool.
•	Participation will take about 60 minutes. As bank details have been registered within the basic survey of the Decision Lab Cologne, participants will be paid by bank transfers. The exact payment will depend on the condition, to which the participant has been assigned to:
      o	No norm/no incentive: Payoff: Participants will receive a fixed payoff of 10€.
      o	Norm/no incentive: Payoff: Participants will receive a fixed payoff of 10€.
      o	No norm/incentive: Payoff: Payoff will consist of 2€ fixed amount plus variable amount from 6€ (chance) to maximum 12€ (all answers correct) with an expected average variable amount of 8€ as it is expected that participants will solve about 2/3 of the tasks.
      o	Norm/Incentive: Payoff: Payoff will consist of 2€ fixed amount plus variable amount from 6€ (chance) to maximum 12€ (all answers correct) with an expected average variable amount of 8€.
Eligibility criteria:
•	Participants will be included, if they:
      o	are aged 18 or above
      o	agreed to the informed consent form
      o	indicated that they have heard of more than 4 of the presented disorders

Study timeline:
•	Decision Lab Cologne-ID
•	Informed consent and data protection notes
•	Random assignment to one of the four conditions (i.e., no norm / no incentive, norm / no incentive, no norm / incentive, norm / incentive)
      o	Presentation of general instructions with regard to the hiring scenario and the performance patterns
      o	Condition-specific instructions (i.e., manipulation)
      o	Test trial and, if applicable, control question(s) with subsequent feedback
      o	Choice of the applicant (i.e., 240 decisions in total)
      o	For each of the two applicants: assessment of the estimated likelihood he or she will be successful
•	Assessment of perceived warmth and competence of each (physical and mental) disorder (i.e., for 20 disorders in total)
•	Assessment of perceived warmth and competence of each occupation (i.e., three occupations in total)
•	Assessment of expected long-term impairment due to each disorder (0-100%)
•	Assessment of estimated percentage of decisions that are solely based on job-related criteria (i.e., manipulation check)
•	Assessment of whether one or more of the disorders are unknown to the participant
•	Assessment of demographic data (i.e., age, gender, participant occupation / student status)

q13.value: The required sample size has been determined a priori by means of G*Power version 3.1.9.2: Based on the central result, the main effect of disorder (mental vs. physical), the effect found in Study 2 (b = -0.749, OR = 0.4728392, p<.001) has been used. More specifically, “F-tests – ANOVA: Repeated measures, within factors” has been chosen as it is the closest approximation to the repeated-measurement regression. The effect size f=0.2065 with two measurements and four groups has been used, since the effect will be tested within each condition. For a power of 1- β = .95 and an alpha probability of 0.05, a sample size of n = 20 participants is required per group, resulting in a total sample size of N = 80 participants.

q15.value: Data collection will be terminated when the desired sample size has been reached.

question.value:
With a within-subject design, following variables will be manipulated:
-	10 mental disorders: alcohol dependence disorder, schizophrenia, major depression, bipolar disorder I, agoraphobia, generalized anxiety disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, posttraumatic-stress-disorder, somatoform pain disorder, anorexia nervosa
-	Job relevant cues: final grades, work experience, working sample, job interview (+/-) varied across four possible patterns adopted from Dorrough et al. (2017; Pattern 3-6). The cue validities will be constant for all trials (for details, please see attached file).
-	Each combination of a certain mental vs. physical disorder will be shown with the opposite pattern of performances (+/-) by changing sides of the presented disorders, because mental and physical disorders will not be fully crossed (for an example, please see attached file).
-	Three occupations: architect, police officer, and department manager
-	Within-subjects variables, which are not fully crossed but counterbalanced across participants:
      o	10 physical disorders will be randomly opposed to the 10 mental disorders (i.e., as the specific physical disorders are not part of the confirmatory analyses, disorders will not be fully crossed with all other factors)
      o	Applicants’ gender will be randomly assigned per trial (i.e., male and male or female and female)
Between-subjects variable:
-	Payment conditions (i.e., interventions): no norm/no incentive; norm/no incentive; no norm/incentive; norm/incentive

•	Manipulation check:
      o	Whether instructions provided in the manipulation have been understood
      o	Estimated percentage of decisions solely based on job-related criteria
•	Dependent variables:
      o	Choice for the more suitable applicant (participants will make 10 (mental disorder) x 4 (patterns) x 3 (occupations) x 2 (opposite patterns) =240 decisions)
      o	Estimated likelihood that applicants V and W will be successful in the occupation (11-point Likert scale from 0 (impossible) to 5 (50:50 Chance) to 10 (certain))
      o	Perceived warmth and competence of…
                - …each mental and physical disorder
                - …each occupation
•	Covariate:
      o	Expected long-term impairment due to disorders (0-100%)
•	Demographic variables:
      o	Participant age 
      o	Participant gender
      o	Participant occupation/student status
Warmth and competence scores will be calculated by averaging across the respective three items (see material).

Manipulation check:
In order to test whether the manipulation of the norm has been successful, an independent-samples t-test will be conducted. More specifically, the estimated percentages of decisions solely based on job-related criteria measured in Conditions 1 and 3 (i.e., conditions not including presentation of norm) will be tested against those measured in Conditions 2 and 4 (i.e., conditions including presentation of norm). The manipulation of the norm will be regarded as successful, if the estimated percentages of decisions solely based on job-related criteria is significantly greater in Conditions 2 and 4 than in Conditions 1 and 3.


Main analyses:
-	H1: Across all conditions, the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is predicted in a rational manner by job relevant cues (positive relation).
-	H2: Across all conditions, the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is higher for applicants with physical as compared to mental disorders (main effect of disorder (i.e., hiring bias)).
-	H3: Across all conditions, the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is influenced negatively by the expected long-term impairment (difference between the more and the less suitable applicant). It is hypothesized that the expected effect of the cue mental vs. physical disorder is (fully or partially) mediated by differences in expected long term impairment.

To test H1, H2, and H3, the choice for the more suitable candidate (yes vs. no) will be predicted by type of disorder (0 = physical disorder; 1 = mental disorder) and the Bayes-posterior probability of the more suitable candidate (i.e., the job relevant information) by means of a logistic regression analysis. As covariates, gender of the candidate pair (0 = male; 1 = female), the difference between both candidates (more suitable minus less suitable) with regard to expected long term impairment, and conditions (1, 2, 3, 4) using three dummy variables with Condition 1 as reference category will be added (i.e., model 1). To account for repeated measurements, cluster correction will be applied. In addition, the aforementioned variables will be included by means of the forced entry method (i.e., will be entered simultaneously).


-	H4: Across all conditions, people with mental as compared to physical disorders are perceived as being less competent (main effect of disorder).

In order to test H4, competence will be predicted by type of disorder (0 = physical disorder; 1 = mental disorder). Moreover, the Bayes-posterior probability of the more suitable applicant, gender of the applicant pair (0 = male; 1 = female), the difference between both applicants with regard to the expected long term impairment, and conditions (1, 2, 3, 4) using three dummy variables with Condition 1 as reference category will be added as covariates (i.e., model 2). Thus, H4 will be tested by means of a multiple linear regression analysis, for which both, a cluster correction as well as the forced entry method will be applied, too.


-	H5: Across all conditions, the expected probability to be successful in the occupation is perceived to be lower for people with mental as compared to physical disorders (main effect of disorder).

To test H5, the expected probability to be successful in the occupation will be predicted by the same independent variable and covariates as described for model 2. For this multiple linear regression analysis, cluster correction and forced entry method will also be applied.


-	H6: Across all conditions, the expected effect of the cue mental vs. physical disorder on the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is (fully or partially) mediated by perceived competence.

To test H6, model 1 will be rerun, adding perceived competence of a certain disorder (difference of the more suitable applicant’s disorder and the less suitable applicant’s disorder) as an additional predictor. Furthermore, a mediation analysis using bootstrapping to estimate standard errors (Preacher & Hayes, 2008) will be conducted.


-	H7.0: It is hypothesized that in Conditions 2 (norm only), 3 (incentive only), and 4 (norm + incentive), the probability to choose the more suitable applicant will be higher in comparison to Condition 1.
      o	H7.1: The probability to choose the more suitable applicant increases with the presence of a social norm (main effect of norm).
      o	H7.2: The probability to choose the more suitable applicant with the presence of monetary incentives (main effect of incentive).

The hypotheses H7.0, H7.1, and H7.2 will be analyzed by means of a logistic regression analysis. More specifically, the choice for the more suitable applicant (yes vs. no) will be predicted by type of disorder (0 = physical disorder; 1 = mental disorder), the Bayes-posterior probability of the more suitable applicant (i.e., the job relevant information), norm (0 = no; 1 = yes), and incentive (0 = no; 1 = yes). As covariates, gender of the candidate pair (0 = male; 1 = female) and the difference between both candidates (more suitable minus less suitable) with regard to expected long term impairment will be added (i.e., model 3). To account for repeated measurements, cluster correction will be applied. In addition, the aforementioned variables will be included by means of the forced entry method.


-	H8: Across all conditions, people with mental as compared to physical disorders are perceived as being less warm (main effect of disorder).

In order to test H8, warmth will be predicted by type of disorder (0 = physical disorder; 1 = mental disorder). Moreover, the Bayes-posterior probability of the more suitable applicant, gender of the applicant pair (0 = male; 1 = female), the difference between both applicants with regard to the expected long term impairment, and conditions (1, 2, 3, 4) using three dummy variables with Condition 1 as reference category will be added as covariates (i.e., model 4). Thus, H8 will be tested by means of a multiple linear regression analysis, for which both, a cluster correction as well as the forced entry method will be applied, too.


-	H9: Across all conditions, the expected effect of the cue mental vs. physical disorder on the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is (fully or partially) mediated by perceived warmth.

For H9, model 1 will be rerun, with perceived warmth of a certain disorder (difference of the perceived warmth of the more suitable applicant’s disorder and the less suitable applicant’s disorder) as an additional predictor. Again, a mediation analysis as described above will be conducted.

q21.value:
For all statistical analyses, a statistical significance level of α = .05 will be applied. For directed hypotheses (i.e., H1, H2, H3, H4, H5, and H8), one-tailed tests will be applied, whereas interaction effects (i.e., H7.0, H7.1, and H7.2) will be analyzed by means of two-sided tests.
For indirect effects in mediation analyses (i.e., H3, H6, and H9), 95% CIs will be used.

q22.value: Missing data will result in exclusion of participants. Given that only mandatory questions will be used, this should just be relevant for dropouts.

q24.value:
In order to exploratively investigate whether the perceived warmth of the disorder moderates the expected effect of type of intervention on the probability to choose the more suitable applicant, the choice for the more suitable candidate (yes vs. no) will be predicted by perceived warmth of a certain disorder, type of disorder (0 = physical disorder; 1 = mental disorder), the Bayes-posterior probability of the more suitable candidate (i.e., the job relevant information), and condition (1, 2, 3, 4) using three dummy variables. As covariates, gender of the candidate pair (0 = male; 1 = female) and the difference between both candidates (more suitable minus less suitable) with regard to expected long term impairment will be added (i.e., model 5). 
The reference category for the dummy-coded condition variable will be Condition 1, meaning that the interaction effects between perceived warmth and Condition 2, Condition 3, and Condition 4, respectively (i.e., three interaction effects) will be examined my closely. Thus, a logistic regression analysis with cluster correction will be applied. In addition, the aforementioned variables will be included by means of the forced entry method.

Following variables will be randomized:

•	occupation
•	presentation order of the 10 mental disorders
•	physical disorders will be randomly opposed to the 10 mental disorders (see also variables section)
•	gender of the applicants (see also variables section)
•	order of the patterns and the corresponding localization of the mental disorder (i.e., instead of reversing the patterns, the mental disorders will be located on either side)
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: The required sample size has been determined a priori by means of G*Power version 3.1.9.2: Based on the central result, the main effect of disorder (mental vs. physical), the effect found in Study 2 (b = -0.749, OR = 0.4728392, p<.001) has been used. More specifically, “F-tests – ANOVA: Repeated measures, within factors” has been chosen as it is the closest approximation to the repeated-measurement regression. The effect size f=0.2065 with two measurements and four groups has been used, since the effect will be tested within each condition. For a power of 1- β = .95 and an alpha probability of 0.05, a sample size of n = 20 participants is required per group, resulting in a total sample size of N = 80 participants.
registration_responses.q15: Data collection will be terminated when the desired sample size has been reached.
registration_responses.q21:
For all statistical analyses, a statistical significance level of α = .05 will be applied. For directed hypotheses (i.e., H1, H2, H3, H4, H5, and H8), one-tailed tests will be applied, whereas interaction effects (i.e., H7.0, H7.1, and H7.2) will be analyzed by means of two-sided tests.
For indirect effects in mediation analyses (i.e., H3, H6, and H9), 95% CIs will be used.
registration_responses.q22: Missing data will result in exclusion of participants. Given that only mandatory questions will be used, this should just be relevant for dropouts.
registration_responses.q24:
In order to exploratively investigate whether the perceived warmth of the disorder moderates the expected effect of type of intervention on the probability to choose the more suitable applicant, the choice for the more suitable candidate (yes vs. no) will be predicted by perceived warmth of a certain disorder, type of disorder (0 = physical disorder; 1 = mental disorder), the Bayes-posterior probability of the more suitable candidate (i.e., the job relevant information), and condition (1, 2, 3, 4) using three dummy variables. As covariates, gender of the candidate pair (0 = male; 1 = female) and the difference between both candidates (more suitable minus less suitable) with regard to expected long term impairment will be added (i.e., model 5). 
The reference category for the dummy-coded condition variable will be Condition 1, meaning that the interaction effects between perceived warmth and Condition 2, Condition 3, and Condition 4, respectively (i.e., three interaction effects) will be examined my closely. Thus, a logistic regression analysis with cluster correction will be applied. In addition, the aforementioned variables will be included by means of the forced entry method.

registration_responses.q8.question: The study design will be a mixed factorial design (for details, see also variables section).
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participant recruitment and payment:
•	Participants will be recruited from the Decision Lab Cologne pool.
•	Participation will take about 60 minutes. As bank details have been registered within the basic survey of the Decision Lab Cologne, participants will be paid by bank transfers. The exact payment will depend on the condition, to which the participant has been assigned to:
      o	No norm/no incentive: Payoff: Participants will receive a fixed payoff of 10€.
      o	Norm/no incentive: Payoff: Participants will receive a fixed payoff of 10€.
      o	No norm/incentive: Payoff: Payoff will consist of 2€ fixed amount plus variable amount from 6€ (chance) to maximum 12€ (all answers correct) with an expected average variable amount of 8€ as it is expected that participants will solve about 2/3 of the tasks.
      o	Norm/Incentive: Payoff: Payoff will consist of 2€ fixed amount plus variable amount from 6€ (chance) to maximum 12€ (all answers correct) with an expected average variable amount of 8€.
Eligibility criteria:
•	Participants will be included, if they:
      o	are aged 18 or above
      o	agreed to the informed consent form
      o	indicated that they have heard of more than 4 of the presented disorders

Study timeline:
•	Decision Lab Cologne-ID
•	Informed consent and data protection notes
•	Random assignment to one of the four conditions (i.e., no norm / no incentive, norm / no incentive, no norm / incentive, norm / incentive)
      o	Presentation of general instructions with regard to the hiring scenario and the performance patterns
      o	Condition-specific instructions (i.e., manipulation)
      o	Test trial and, if applicable, control question(s) with subsequent feedback
      o	Choice of the applicant (i.e., 240 decisions in total)
      o	For each of the two applicants: assessment of the estimated likelihood he or she will be successful
•	Assessment of perceived warmth and competence of each (physical and mental) disorder (i.e., for 20 disorders in total)
•	Assessment of perceived warmth and competence of each occupation (i.e., three occupations in total)
•	Assessment of expected long-term impairment due to each disorder (0-100%)
•	Assessment of estimated percentage of decisions that are solely based on job-related criteria (i.e., manipulation check)
•	Assessment of whether one or more of the disorders are unknown to the participant
•	Assessment of demographic data (i.e., age, gender, participant occupation / student status)
registration_responses.q16.question:
With a within-subject design, following variables will be manipulated:
-	10 mental disorders: alcohol dependence disorder, schizophrenia, major depression, bipolar disorder I, agoraphobia, generalized anxiety disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, posttraumatic-stress-disorder, somatoform pain disorder, anorexia nervosa
-	Job relevant cues: final grades, work experience, working sample, job interview (+/-) varied across four possible patterns adopted from Dorrough et al. (2017; Pattern 3-6). The cue validities will be constant for all trials (for details, please see attached file).
-	Each combination of a certain mental vs. physical disorder will be shown with the opposite pattern of performances (+/-) by changing sides of the presented disorders, because mental and physical disorders will not be fully crossed (for an example, please see attached file).
-	Three occupations: architect, police officer, and department manager
-	Within-subjects variables, which are not fully crossed but counterbalanced across participants:
      o	10 physical disorders will be randomly opposed to the 10 mental disorders (i.e., as the specific physical disorders are not part of the confirmatory analyses, disorders will not be fully crossed with all other factors)
      o	Applicants’ gender will be randomly assigned per trial (i.e., male and male or female and female)
Between-subjects variable:
-	Payment conditions (i.e., interventions): no norm/no incentive; norm/no incentive; no norm/incentive; norm/incentive
registration_responses.q17.question:
•	Manipulation check:
      o	Whether instructions provided in the manipulation have been understood
      o	Estimated percentage of decisions solely based on job-related criteria
•	Dependent variables:
      o	Choice for the more suitable applicant (participants will make 10 (mental disorder) x 4 (patterns) x 3 (occupations) x 2 (opposite patterns) =240 decisions)
      o	Estimated likelihood that applicants V and W will be successful in the occupation (11-point Likert scale from 0 (impossible) to 5 (50:50 Chance) to 10 (certain))
      o	Perceived warmth and competence of…
                - …each mental and physical disorder
                - …each occupation
•	Covariate:
      o	Expected long-term impairment due to disorders (0-100%)
•	Demographic variables:
      o	Participant age 
      o	Participant gender
      o	Participant occupation/student status
registration_responses.q18.question: Warmth and competence scores will be calculated by averaging across the respective three items (see material).
registration_responses.q19.question:
Manipulation check:
In order to test whether the manipulation of the norm has been successful, an independent-samples t-test will be conducted. More specifically, the estimated percentages of decisions solely based on job-related criteria measured in Conditions 1 and 3 (i.e., conditions not including presentation of norm) will be tested against those measured in Conditions 2 and 4 (i.e., conditions including presentation of norm). The manipulation of the norm will be regarded as successful, if the estimated percentages of decisions solely based on job-related criteria is significantly greater in Conditions 2 and 4 than in Conditions 1 and 3.


Main analyses:
-	H1: Across all conditions, the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is predicted in a rational manner by job relevant cues (positive relation).
-	H2: Across all conditions, the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is higher for applicants with physical as compared to mental disorders (main effect of disorder (i.e., hiring bias)).
-	H3: Across all conditions, the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is influenced negatively by the expected long-term impairment (difference between the more and the less suitable applicant). It is hypothesized that the expected effect of the cue mental vs. physical disorder is (fully or partially) mediated by differences in expected long term impairment.

To test H1, H2, and H3, the choice for the more suitable candidate (yes vs. no) will be predicted by type of disorder (0 = physical disorder; 1 = mental disorder) and the Bayes-posterior probability of the more suitable candidate (i.e., the job relevant information) by means of a logistic regression analysis. As covariates, gender of the candidate pair (0 = male; 1 = female), the difference between both candidates (more suitable minus less suitable) with regard to expected long term impairment, and conditions (1, 2, 3, 4) using three dummy variables with Condition 1 as reference category will be added (i.e., model 1). To account for repeated measurements, cluster correction will be applied. In addition, the aforementioned variables will be included by means of the forced entry method (i.e., will be entered simultaneously).


-	H4: Across all conditions, people with mental as compared to physical disorders are perceived as being less competent (main effect of disorder).

In order to test H4, competence will be predicted by type of disorder (0 = physical disorder; 1 = mental disorder). Moreover, the Bayes-posterior probability of the more suitable applicant, gender of the applicant pair (0 = male; 1 = female), the difference between both applicants with regard to the expected long term impairment, and conditions (1, 2, 3, 4) using three dummy variables with Condition 1 as reference category will be added as covariates (i.e., model 2). Thus, H4 will be tested by means of a multiple linear regression analysis, for which both, a cluster correction as well as the forced entry method will be applied, too.


-	H5: Across all conditions, the expected probability to be successful in the occupation is perceived to be lower for people with mental as compared to physical disorders (main effect of disorder).

To test H5, the expected probability to be successful in the occupation will be predicted by the same independent variable and covariates as described for model 2. For this multiple linear regression analysis, cluster correction and forced entry method will also be applied.


-	H6: Across all conditions, the expected effect of the cue mental vs. physical disorder on the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is (fully or partially) mediated by perceived competence.

To test H6, model 1 will be rerun, adding perceived competence of a certain disorder (difference of the more suitable applicant’s disorder and the less suitable applicant’s disorder) as an additional predictor. Furthermore, a mediation analysis using bootstrapping to estimate standard errors (Preacher & Hayes, 2008) will be conducted.


-	H7.0: It is hypothesized that in Conditions 2 (norm only), 3 (incentive only), and 4 (norm + incentive), the probability to choose the more suitable applicant will be higher in comparison to Condition 1.
      o	H7.1: The probability to choose the more suitable applicant increases with the presence of a social norm (main effect of norm).
      o	H7.2: The probability to choose the more suitable applicant with the presence of monetary incentives (main effect of incentive).

The hypotheses H7.0, H7.1, and H7.2 will be analyzed by means of a logistic regression analysis. More specifically, the choice for the more suitable applicant (yes vs. no) will be predicted by type of disorder (0 = physical disorder; 1 = mental disorder), the Bayes-posterior probability of the more suitable applicant (i.e., the job relevant information), norm (0 = no; 1 = yes), and incentive (0 = no; 1 = yes). As covariates, gender of the candidate pair (0 = male; 1 = female) and the difference between both candidates (more suitable minus less suitable) with regard to expected long term impairment will be added (i.e., model 3). To account for repeated measurements, cluster correction will be applied. In addition, the aforementioned variables will be included by means of the forced entry method.


-	H8: Across all conditions, people with mental as compared to physical disorders are perceived as being less warm (main effect of disorder).

In order to test H8, warmth will be predicted by type of disorder (0 = physical disorder; 1 = mental disorder). Moreover, the Bayes-posterior probability of the more suitable applicant, gender of the applicant pair (0 = male; 1 = female), the difference between both applicants with regard to the expected long term impairment, and conditions (1, 2, 3, 4) using three dummy variables with Condition 1 as reference category will be added as covariates (i.e., model 4). Thus, H8 will be tested by means of a multiple linear regression analysis, for which both, a cluster correction as well as the forced entry method will be applied, too.


-	H9: Across all conditions, the expected effect of the cue mental vs. physical disorder on the probability to choose the more suitable applicant is (fully or partially) mediated by perceived warmth.

For H9, model 1 will be rerun, with perceived warmth of a certain disorder (difference of the perceived warmth of the more suitable applicant’s disorder and the less suitable applicant’s disorder) as an additional predictor. Again, a mediation analysis as described above will be conducted.

summary.value:
Temporal Explanations Registration (TX2)

Explanations can help resolve conflicts in information (Khemlani, 2018). Some explanations are non-causal in nature, but the vast majority of contemporary research into explanatory reasoning concerns causal explanations. For instance, a causal explanation for why, e.g., Ria was late to a meeting is that his car broke down. Previous studies show that people spontaneously generate causal explanations when they detect that a set of premises is inconsistent (Khemlani & Johnson-Laird, 2011). In this study, we test whether people spontaneously produce non-causal, temporal explanations when provided with an inconsistent set of premises. Temporal explanations are explanations that appeal to events and their relations to one another in time. A temporal explanation for why Ria was late to work would be, e.g., that the meeting was rescheduled -- and so Ria was not, in fact, late. The explanation appeals to temporal, not causal relations, to resolve conflicts.

The materials of our previous experiment (TX1) seemed to have been too complicated. In this experiment, participants are told 2 facts: 

1. The interval of an event such as: "The party was scheduled to occur from 7pm to 10pm on Friday."
2. The time of an individual's arrival, such as: "Gerald arrived at the party at 10:30pm on Friday."

The participant is told they discovered another fact:
3. The individual was at the event: Gerald attended the party.

And they are asked an open-response question: "What, if anything, follows?" 

In this case, there is a conflict such that the party was supposed to end before Gerald arrived but we also know that he attended the party. Participants who notice the temporal conflict may state that one of the facts is simply wrong or they could generate an explanation, e.g., The party ran late.  We varied the first fact so that there was or was not a temporal conflict, e.g., The party was scheduled to occur from 7pm to 12am on Friday.  With this information, there is no temporal conflict: Gerald arrived while the party was supposed to be happening.  Participants could still generate explanations such as: Gerald got a flat on the way to the party and therefore was late.

Each problem is designed with a consistent and an inconsistent version. Each participant will be randomly assigned the inconsistent version of 4 problems and the consistent version of the other 4. It is our prediction that there will be more explanations, and in particular temporal explanations, for the inconsistent problems than for the consistent problems. The responses will be coded for 1. whether an explanation is given and 2. type of explanation (temporal or something else).  We will use a Wilcoxon test of consistency  and confirm those results with a linear mixed effect regression model with consistency as the fixed factor; and with participants and items as random factors (intercept and random slopes by consistency).

We will collect 50 participants via Amazon Mechanical Turk with a payment of $2.00.

attributes.title: Commercial Videogames in Stroke Rehabilitation: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis
attributes.description: Commercial video games are used as a tool for stroke rehabilitation. However, the studies present heterogeneity and we are not sure about their effectiveness. This study aims to carry out a systematic review and meta-analysis of all the studies that use commercial videogames in the comprehensive rehabilitation (physical and cognitive) of stroke and it wants to verify if they are an effective tool for stroke rehabilitation.

q1.value: Commercial Videogames in Stroke Rehabilitation: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis

q3.value: Commercial video games are used as a tool for stroke rehabilitation. However, the studies present heterogeneity and we are not sure about their effectiveness. This study aims to carry out a systematic review and meta-analysis of all the studies that use commercial videogames in the comprehensive rehabilitation (physical and cognitive) of stroke and it wants to verify if they are an effective tool for stroke rehabilitation.

q4.value: We expect that commercial video games have a greater effect than conventional rehabilitation in people who have suffered a stroke.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A meta-analysis will be conducted

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: As this is a meta-analysis, data will be collected from eligible studies

question.value:
Data collection: We search in of EBSCOhost, PubMed, MEDLINE, IEEE Xplore digital library, PsycINFO, PsycARTICLES, Psicodoc, Emeral, Dialnet, Web of Science, PROQUEST, and Google Scholar.
Types of study to be included: both observational and experimental (that get 6 or more in PEDro Scale), on the use of commercial video games in the rehabilitation of patients with stroke. 
Types of study to be excluded: All articles that included healthy people or those with other pathology. Also articles with used virtual reality, biofeedback, or noncommercial video games as well as qualitative studies, single-subject studies or those with a sample size of ≤5, doctoral theses, reviews and/or meta-analysis, abstracts, newspaper articles, and news.
The full text of all articles identified from the search will be preliminarily reviewed by two independent trained reviewers for eligibility. Researchers will extract the necessary data from the articles. When the data are not available, the authors will be contacted and invited to submit the necessary data. Once the data are received, they will be recorded to analyze.
Therefore, there are two procedures, on the one hand, we analyze all observational studies and, on the other hand, only experimental studies that obtained 6 or more scores on the PEDro scale were analyzing, validating the great experimental quality and reducing the risk of bias.
Main outcomes: functionality, balance, quality of movement, gait speed, motivation, motor mobility, attention, quality of life, and cognition.
Statistic data to be entered for analysis: In observational studies, we will use the number of participants, the mean, and standard deviation for the baseline and for the post-intervention measure. In experimental studies, we will use the number of participants and the mean differences and the standard deviation differences between baseline and post-intervention time. Heterogeneity will be determined using the I2 statistic and the total effect will be calculated using Z and p-values. For these, we will use RevMan 5.3 software.

q13.value: Not applicable. This is a meta-analysis.

question.value: Commercial video games: video games that are available in the stores (for example Nintendo Wii, Xbox, etc.) VS Conventional Rehabilitation (physiotherapy, occupational therapy, etc.).

Functionality: Fulg–Meyer Assessment, Functional Reach Test, Wolf Motor Function Test, Brunnstrom Approach, Functional Independence Measure, ARAT, Modified Motor Assessment Scale, Functional Ambulatory Category, Grip strength-strong hand
Balance: Berg Balance Scale, Step Test, Postural Assessment Scale, Activity Specific Balance Confidence Test, Sitting Balance, Test Tinitti Gait
Quality of Movement: Motor Activity Log Quality of Movement, Falls Efficacy Scale, Stroke Rehabilitation Assessment of Movement, Active Range Motion
Motivation: Intrinsic Motivation Inventory (IMI) 
Gait Speed: 6-min walk test, 10-Meter Walk Test, Dynamic Gait Index, 3 Meter Walk Test
Mobility: Timed Get Up and Go test, Modified Ashworth Scale, Motricity Index
Attention: Color Trials Test, TMT
Quality of life: Stroke Impact Scale, Barthel Index, SF36, Nottingham Health Profile, Frenchay Activity Index, Occupational Performance Measure Satisfaction
Cognition: Box and Block Test, K-MMSE. Auditory continuous performance test, visual continuous performance test, Executive Function Performance Test, Cognitive Abilities Screening, Digit Span WAISTest
Random-effects model. Heterogeneity will be determined using the I2 statistic and the total effect will be calculated using Z and p-values.

q20.value:
We will use the number of participants, the mean and the standard deviation. However, if
articles bring the standard error or confidence of intervales we will transform them into a standard deviation, using  Formula 1 and 2 in Colton T. Statistics in Medicine. Boston: Little Brown & Co (T); 1974. For experimental studies, we will calculate the standard deviation differences between pre-post time. In those cases, we will calculate the standard deviation difference with Formula 8 in Lakens D. Calculating and reporting effects sizes to facilitate cumulative science: a practical primer for t-test and ANOVAs. FRONT PSYCHOL. 2013; 4(863): 1-12. doi: 10.3389/fpsyg.2013.00863 . In case of needing r , we will use 0.05, following the recommendation of Lipsey MW, Wilson DB. Practical Meta-Analysis. California: SAGE Publications; 2001.

q22.value: Experimental studies with getting 5 or fewer scores in PEDro Scale and studies with other pathology or which not use commercial videogames.

q23.value: Only studies with available data in the published articles or given by the authors of the articles will be used.

attributes.title: Rising Incidence and Incidence-Mortality of Thyroid Cancer in California, 2000-2017: Supplemental Tables

summary.value: In our clinical outcomes study, we conducted a retrospective analysis of the California Cancer Registry from 2000-2017 to assess trends in incidence and incidence-based mortality of Thyroid cancer in California. Our analysis produced original data, figures and tables included for a manuscript. The tables that we are unable to include in our manuscript will be put in this registration as supplemental tables for public access in this data repository. This includes tables assessing the annual percent change in Incidence (Supplemental Table 1) and Incidence-Based Mortality (Supplemental Table 2) of thyroid cancer from 2000-2017.

attributes.title: Anxiety and Terrorism : Stereotype Activation Affect on Visual Attention following Media Exposure

q1.value: Anxiety and Terrorism : Stereotype Activation Affect on Visual Attention following Media Exposure

q3.value: News coverage following terrorist attacks can have an effect on attitudes towards racial and ethnic groups along with influencing psychological states such as anxiety. The present research aims to study how anxiety levels can influence the unconscious activation of terrorism related stereotypes from the news coverage of such attacks. The repeated focus which is given to religious affiliation following these type of terror attacks can lead to an association being made between terrorism and the Islamic faith which then forms an unconscious stereotype in the public mind. This study examines patterns of visual attention following exposure to terrorism related headlines which do not specify the ethnicity or religious orientation of those involved. The key research question is whether individuals with higher anxiety levels are more susceptible to stereotypes related to middle eastern individuals and terrorism and if these stereotypes are activated through media headlines.

q4.value:
Are high anxious participants more susceptible to stereotype activation and do these stereotypes affect visual attention? 
Do anxiety and stereotypes of Middle Eastern individuals in news media affect visual attention?

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study is will be a between and within subject’s design investigating the association between anxiety levels and the likelihood of automatic stereotype activation in response to priming with terror related news media. The dependent variable in this study is the reaction time to respond to the location of the dot in the dot probe task. The independent variable in this study is the levels of state and trait anxiety with higher levels of anxiety predicted to cause selective visual attention to middle eastern faces following the news headline priming condition. The location of the dot in the dot probe task will vary within subjects.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from the psychology students in the National University of Ireland, Galway through the mandatory research participation system SONA. Participants are not required to be a particular age, gender or nationality for the current research project and as such the participation will be open to all individuals willing to participate

q13.value: The target sample size is 60 participants, an attempt will be made to recruit 80.

q15.value: Participant sign up slots will be available each week, with 20 slots posted per week in an attempt to recruit the full sample.

question.value: The exposure to news media will be manipulated with the control group being exposed a no prime condition in which an X appears on alternating sides of the screen and the experimental group being exposed to terrorism related headlines. The location of the dot in the dot probe task will vary within subjects.

The dependent variable in this study is the reaction time to respond to the location of the dot in the dot probe task. This will be measured by the time taken to perform the keyboard press for the location of the dot. 
The independent variable in this study is the levels of state and trait anxiety measured using the State Trait Anxiety Inventory.

A two way mixed ANOVA (condition - no prime vs prime, dot position - middle eastern vs white). Two three way mixed ANOVAs, the first including trait anxiety with the condition and dot position and the second including state anxiety instead of trait anxiety.

attributes.title: A systematic review of the literature applying the Verona Coding Definitions of Emotional Sequences (VR-CoDES) in research.

q2.value: Brett Andersen, Laith Al-Shawaf, Rachel Bearden

q3.value: Does personality variation related to autism and/or positive schizotypy correlate with the intention or desire to migrate?

q4.value:
1) The principal components analysis structure from previous studies will be approximately replicated (meaning that the first component will represent social difficulty and the second component will represent a continuum with autistic traits on one end and schizotypy on the other). 

2) The second component (i.e., autism-schizotypy) will correlate with intentions and desires to migrate.

3) The relationship described in 2) will be mediated by metatrait Plasticity (the shared variance between Openness/Intellect and Extraversion).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Cross sectional correlational study. All details are in the attached document.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Qualtrics will handle data collection. Participants must be between the ages of 18 and 25, non-immigrants, and United States citizens living in the US in the state in which they were born. Qualtrics also disqualifies speeders (i.e., those who finish so fast that they couldn't have answered the questions thoughtfully) and straight-liners (i.e., those who give the same answer to many items or use an identifiable pattern to answer the items). 

Outliers will be considered, and if found, we will perform robustness tests to see how much influence they have (e.g., by doing the regression with and without outliers, reporting both sets of results).

q13.value: N = 227, but Qualtrics may overshoot this number so the N may be up to 250.

question.value:
12.	Measured variables
12.1.	Schizotypy
12.1.1.	The schizotypal personality questionnaire is a self-report measure meant to assess schizotypal traits in the general population. It has 74 yes/no items. There are nine subscales:
12.1.1.1.	Three positive schizotypy subscales: Magical thinking, unusual perceptual experiences, and ideas of reference.
12.1.1.2.	Three negative schizotypy subscales: Social anxiety, constricted affect, and no close friends.
12.1.1.3.	Three disorganization subscales: Odd/eccentric behavior, odd speech, and suspiciousness.
12.2.	Autistic-like traits
12.2.1.	The autism quotient is a self-report measure meant to assess autistic-like traits in the general population. It has 50 self-report items on a four-point scale (from 1: Definitely Agree to 4: Definitely Disagree). There are five subscales:
12.2.1.1.	Communication
12.2.1.2.	Social skills
12.2.1.3.	Attention switching
12.2.1.4.	Imagination
12.2.1.5.	Attention to detail
12.3.	Intentions and desires to migrate
12.3.1.	For desires, there will be three items measured on a 5-point scale from “not at all” to “extremely”. The items will read: 
12.3.1.1.	How appealing to you is the idea of living in a different town within your native state? 
12.3.1.2.	How appealing to you is the idea of living in a different state?
12.3.1.3.	How appealing to you is the idea of living in a different country?
12.3.2.	For intentions, there will be three items with a dichotomous yes/no response. The items will read:
12.3.2.1.	Do you have plans to move to a different town within your native state in the future?
12.3.2.2.	Do you have plans to move to a different state in the future?
12.3.2.3.	Do you have plans to move to a different country in the future?
12.4.	Big Five Aspects Scale
12.4.1.	100 items, measures the normal Big Five traits and breaks them down into two aspects each. Answered on a 5-point scale.

Analysis Plan

13.	Statistical models
13.1.	A principal components analysis with no rotations will be performed on the 14 subscales of the AQ and the SPQ. 
13.2.	If the structure found in previous studies is replicated, we will use the 2nd component to test our main hypotheses (discussed below). 
13.3.	If the structure is not replicated, we will composite autism and schizotypy scores (i.e., the total scores on the AQ and SPQ), entering them both into the regression.
13.4.	The six migration items will be subjected to dimension reduction via PCA with an exploratory approach. We will interpret and use whatever factors are produced from this PCA as the outcome variables.   
13.5.	In order to test the main hypotheses we will use multiple regression with the 2nd component from the first PCA (called autism-schizotypy) as the predictor variable, the outcome measure after dimension reduction (whatever results from the second PCA) as the outcome variable, with age and sex as covariates. 
13.6.	To test for robustness, we will also re-run the regression(s) while taking into consideration the false discovery rate.

q22.value:
14.	Data exclusion – we should not have to exclude any data because Qualtrics will exclude all participants who do not meet the requirements. The requirements are:
14.1.	18-25 years old
14.2.	Born and raised in the United States (i.e., not an immigrant).
14.3.	Currently residing in the state they were born in.
14.4.	Outliers will be considered, and if found, we will perform robustness tests to see how much influence they have (e.g., by doing the regression with and without outliers, reporting both sets of results).

q24.value:
15.	Exploratory analysis
15.1.	If the PCA structure from previous studies isn’t replicated (see section 13.3) we will also perform exploratory analysis using the individual subscales of the AQ and SPQ, since the total scores may be confounded with ‘social difficulty’ (see Del Giudice et al., 2014).

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value:
Counterfactual Curiosity - One-shot Task

This experiment is a follow-up to the five experiments reported in our pre-print "The Lure of Counterfactual Curiosity" (DOI: https://doi.org/10.31219/osf.io/jm3uc). These studies address the question of whether people seek post-decision counterfactual information - how much they could have won - in a gambling task (the Balloon Analogue Risk Task, BART; Lejuez et al., 2002). In previous studies we used a within-participant design, presenting participants with 60 trials of the BART and giving them the option to view the balloon's limit after each trial. Participants frequently sought information even at some cost even though a. it made them feel bad, and b. (we argue that) it had no instrumental value. Our argument that the information had no instrumental value relied on the independent nature of the trials in the task - since the balloon's limit was randomly determined on each trial - so gaining information about the limit on the previous trial cannot benefit performance on future trials. However, it may be argued that participants believe that there is some non-random structure that can be learned through seeking information about the balloon's limit. Thus, they might have sought information for instrumental reasons, even though the information was actually not of any instrumental value. 

In the current study, we aim to demonstrate that people will still incur costs to learn post-decision counterfactual information when the possibility to use that information in the future is completely removed because there is only one trial and that information still makes them feel bad. In the new version of the task, participants practice by completing 10 trials of the BART with no option to seek information. They rate their emotions on a visual analogue scale after seeing the outcome of each trial. 

After the 10 practice trials, participants receive the following instructions: "Now that you've had a chance to practice, it's time for the real thing! There is one more round and this time each pump is worth 20p!". They then complete one critical round of the BART. If participants 'go bust' on this final round, then they do not get a bonus payment and they are not offered the opportunity to see how far they could have gone. If they 'banked' the money, then after rating their emotions about the outcome, then they are given the following instructions: "You won £X.XX. Would you like to see how much you could have won if you kept going? The information comes at a price - you will have to wait 30 seconds for your completion code at the end of the experiment! Press Y for yes or N for no.". 

If they choose to see the information, then they see an animation of the balloon inflating to its randomly determined limit and are presented with information about how much money they could have won on the trial. If they choose not to receive the information then they continue to observe their obtained outcome for the same time as if they had chosen to view the information. Participants then rate their emotions a second time. This second emotion rating is the critical dependent variable.

other.value:
Data collection before the study: 
Data from 18 participants has been collected in a pilot phase to determine whether people are willing to wait 30 seconds at the end of the experiment in return for seeing the balloon's limit. Of those 18 participants, 10 participants stopped before the balloon's limit so banked the money. Of those, 8 sought information about how much they could have won, and 2 did not seek information. The remaining 8 participants 'went bust' so were not given the opportunity to see the balloon's limit. These pilot participants will not be included in the final sample. From this pilot phase we determined that the parameters of our design are suitable to elicit both choices to and not to seek information. This is crucial for comparing emotion ratings between those who did and did not seek information. No other designs were piloted.

Additional analyses planned:
Following our previous analyses, we will determine the effect of the size of the missed opportunity on emotion ratings for those who observed the missed opportunity while controlling for the number of pumps. We will also run the same analysis on those who did not seek information as a check for any statistical artefacts (we do not expect to see any effect since participants did not observe the missed opportunity).

Additionally, we are interested in the change in emotion rating that the information brought, so we will compare difference scores between the two information ratings between participants who did and did not seek information.

sample.value: We will collect data from 360 adult participants using the participant recruitment platform Prolific.co. Based on our previous studies using a within-participant design, we expected to see a medium to large effect of counterfactual information seeking on emotion ratings. Based on our pilot data (described below), we expected an uneven distribution between those who sought and those who did not seek information. We used G-Power to determine the sample size required for the between subjects t-test with uneven groups. We used the following parameters: tails = 2; Cohen's d = 0.5; alpha = 0.05; power = 0.8; Allocation ration N2/N1 = 0.25. This gives a minimum sample of 200 participants. Note that this analysis will only contain participants who did not 'go bust'. In our pilot, 8 out of 18 participants 'went bust', we will thus increase our sample by an additional 160 participants to achieve the required number of participants who do not go bust.

outliers.value:
Unlike in our previous experiments, participants who 'go bust' in the critical trial will not be offered the chance to see how far they could have inflated the balloon, so will not be included in the analysis. We decided not to use 'false feedback' to ensure that all participants banked in the task because we did not want to deceive the participants in any way during this task. We were concerned that using false feedback may introduce statistical artefacts into our design because of potential biases in participants' bidding behaviour.

The recruitment platform pre-screened participants for English as a first language before participation to ensure easy understanding of the task instructions.

dependent.value: Emotion ratings measured on a visual analogue scale will be compared between participants who chose to learn how much they could have won and those who did not.

conditions.value: There is not straightforward condition assignment. Each trial has a randomly determined 'safe limit' (sampled from a uniform distribution between 0 and 12) and the outcome of the trial is determined by whether the participant's bid (i.e. the number of inflations of the balloon they make) exceeds that number. So on some trials the balloon would burst after just one pump, and on others it would not burst after 12 (the maximum number) of pumps. This is randomly determined in the experiment script. Participants can choose whether they wish to seek information (the independent variable in our main emotion rating analysis), so this is outside the control of the experiment. The amount of money the participant missed out on (the missed opportunity they can learn about) is determined by a combination of the participant's bid and the randomly determined safe limit of the balloon.

hypothesis.value: Do people who seek counterfactual information feel worse than those who do not seek counterfactual information?

Additional analyses planned:
Following our previous analyses, we will determine the effect of the size of the missed opportunity on emotion ratings for those who observed the missed opportunity while controlling for the number of pumps. We will also run the same analysis on those who did not seek information as a check for any statistical artefacts (we do not expect to see any effect since participants did not observe the missed opportunity).

Additionally, we are interested in the change in emotion rating that the information brought, so we will compare difference scores between the two information ratings between participants who did and did not seek information.
registration_responses.sample: We will collect data from 360 adult participants using the participant recruitment platform Prolific.co. Based on our previous studies using a within-participant design, we expected to see a medium to large effect of counterfactual information seeking on emotion ratings. Based on our pilot data (described below), we expected an uneven distribution between those who sought and those who did not seek information. We used G-Power to determine the sample size required for the between subjects t-test with uneven groups. We used the following parameters: tails = 2; Cohen's d = 0.5; alpha = 0.05; power = 0.8; Allocation ration N2/N1 = 0.25. This gives a minimum sample of 200 participants. Note that this analysis will only contain participants who did not 'go bust'. In our pilot, 8 out of 18 participants 'went bust', we will thus increase our sample by an additional 160 participants to achieve the required number of participants who do not go bust.
registration_responses.outliers:
Unlike in our previous experiments, participants who 'go bust' in the critical trial will not be offered the chance to see how far they could have inflated the balloon, so will not be included in the analysis. We decided not to use 'false feedback' to ensure that all participants banked in the task because we did not want to deceive the participants in any way during this task. We were concerned that using false feedback may introduce statistical artefacts into our design because of potential biases in participants' bidding behaviour.

The recruitment platform pre-screened participants for English as a first language before participation to ensure easy understanding of the task instructions.
registration_responses.dependent: Emotion ratings measured on a visual analogue scale will be compared between participants who chose to learn how much they could have won and those who did not.
registration_responses.conditions: There is not straightforward condition assignment. Each trial has a randomly determined 'safe limit' (sampled from a uniform distribution between 0 and 12) and the outcome of the trial is determined by whether the participant's bid (i.e. the number of inflations of the balloon they make) exceeds that number. So on some trials the balloon would burst after just one pump, and on others it would not burst after 12 (the maximum number) of pumps. This is randomly determined in the experiment script. Participants can choose whether they wish to seek information (the independent variable in our main emotion rating analysis), so this is outside the control of the experiment. The amount of money the participant missed out on (the missed opportunity they can learn about) is determined by a combination of the participant's bid and the randomly determined safe limit of the balloon.
registration_responses.hypothesis: Do people who seek counterfactual information feel worse than those who do not seek counterfactual information?

attributes.title: The influence of beliefs on the effectiveness of cognitive training

q1.value: The influence of participant beliefs on the effectiveness of cognitive training

q3.value:
Although much research has investigated the role of cognitive training in eating behaviours (Houben & Jansen, 2010; Jones et al., 2016) the results are far from consistent. While some work has found this type of training to be extremely effective in improving healthy choices, other work has found no effects of training on consumption (Hollands & Marteau, 2016). One potential suggestion could be related to participant expectations from training participation (i.e. do they believe training is effective). Unfortunately, these beliefs, or awareness of experimental aims are not consistently measured within the research area, and recent work within the health psychology field discovered an association between contingency awareness healthier choices (Zerhouni et al., 2019). 

No work to date has examined how direct manipulation of participant beliefs related to training influences training outcomes in relation to healthy and unhealthy food preferences, and how this may link with training content (either active training or control 'sham' training).

q4.value:
H1 - Participants who receive active Inhibitory Control training (ICT) and a positive message related to training effectiveness will show greater changes in food value compared to other training groups
H2 - Participants who receive active training and a positive message related to training effectiveness will make healthier explicit choices in comparison to other training groups.
H3 - Participants who receive positive message alone (and sham/control training) and active training (with no positive message) with show greater changes in food value and make healthier explicit choices, compared to a group with no positive message and sham/control training.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The study will have a 4 x 2 mixed design with 1 between subjects factor of condition with 4 levels (ICT and positive message, ICT and no message, sham/control training and positive message, sham/control training and no message) and 1 within subjects factor of time with 2 levels (pre and post training).

q9.value: Simple randomisation (without stratification) will be used, utilising a random number generator.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Prolific academic and will be reimbursed ~ £3 for their time spent (approximately 25-30 minutes). Participants will also be recruited through posters placed at the University of Liverpool (and surrounding areas), and will be entered into a prize draw for one of two £50 amazon vouchers if recruited through this method.

q13.value: The target sample size is 128 participants (as based on a power calculation), however, we will aim to over sample if possible to allow for more accurate effect measures.

q14.value:
F tests - ANOVA: Repeated measures, within-between interaction
Analysis: A priori: Compute required sample size
Input: Effect size f = 0.15
α err prob = 0.05
Power (1-β err prob) = 0.8
Number of groups = 4
Repetitions = 2
Corr among rep measures = 0.5
Nonsphericity correction ε = 1
Output: Noncentrality parameter λ = 11.520000
Critical F = 2.677699
Numerator df = 3.000000
Denominator df = 124
Total sample size = 128
Actual power = 0.810195

q15.value: Data collection procedures allow full control over the exact sample size.

question.value: Participants will be randomly allocated to one of 4 experimental conditions. The first group will receive a message prior to training explaining the positive benefits of training, while the second group will not receive any message prior to training. The third group will receive the same positive message as group 1 before completing sham training, and the final group will receive no message prior to completing sham training.

Food value will be measured using visual analogue scales (VAS), where participants will be presented with healthy and unhealthy food images and asked to rate the images in terms of appeal on a scale of -100 (not at all appealing) to +100 (very appealing). 
Explicit preference will be measured using a forced choice task, where participants will be asked to select a food item that they would most like to consume from a variety of healthy and unhealthy items.
Mean scores will be used when calculating food value measurements (VAS) for healthy and unhealthy foods.

H1 and H3 - This will be tested with a 4 x 2 ANOVA. The IVs are condition (between) and time (within), with the DV as food value.  
H2 - This will be tested with a one way ANOVA. The IV is condition (between) and the DV is explicit food preference.

q20.value: For explicit preferences, participants will make a selection from a variety of healthy and unhealthy food items. Food items will be classified as healthy or unhealthy based upon their nutritional content, and will be scored as +1 for a healthy selection, and 0 for an unhealthy selection.

q21.value: The standard p<.05 will be used to determine statistical significance for the analyses, with the proposed post-hoc test (Tukey's HSD) automatically adjusting for multiple comparisons.

q22.value: Outliers for the DVs will be examined using box plots. Data will be analysed and reported both with and without outliers.

q23.value: Data from participants who do not complete all parts of the experiment will be excluded.

q24.value: Any analysis not reported above will be marked as exploratory in any form of dissemination.
